awd_titl_txt: NSFGEO-NERC: Mechanisms of Adaptation to Terrestrial Antarctica through Comparative Physiology and Genomics of Antarctic and sub-Antarctic Insects
awd_abstract_narration:
The cold, dry terrestrial environments of Antarctica are inhospitable for insects, and only three midge species make Antarctica home. Of these, Belgica antarctica is the only species found exclusively in Antarctica, and it has been a resident of Antarctica since the continent split from South America ~30 million years ago. Thus, this species is an excellent system to model the biological history of Antarctica throughout its repeated glaciation events and shifts in climate. This insect is also a classic example of extreme adaptation, and much previous work has focused on identifying the genetic and physiological mechanisms that allow this species to survive where no other insect is capable. However, it has been difficult to pinpoint the unique evolutionary adaptations that are required to survive in Antarctica due to a lack of information from closely related Antarctic and sub-Antarctic species. This project will compare adaptations, genome sequences, and population characteristics of four midge species that span an environmental gradient from sub-Antarctic to Antarctic habitats. In addition to B. antarctica, these species include two species that are strictly sub-Antarctic and a third that is native to the sub-Antarctic but has invaded parts of Antarctica. The researchers, comprised of scientists from the US, UK, Chile, and France, will sample insects from across their geographic range and measure their ability to tolerate environmental stressors (i.e., cold and desiccation), quantify molecular responses to stress, and compare the makeup of the genome and patterns of genetic diversity. This research will contribute to a greater understanding of adaptation to extremes, to an understanding of biodiversity on the planet and to understanding and predicting changes accompanying environmental change. The project will train two graduate students and two postdoctoral researchers, and a K-12 educator will be a member of the field team and will assist with fieldwork and facilitate outreach with schools in the US. The project includes partnership activities with several STEM education organizations to deliver educational content to K-12 and secondary students. This is a project that is jointly funded by the National Science Foundation's Directorate of Geosciences (NSF/GEO) and the National Environment Research Council (NERC) of the United Kingdom (UK) via the NSF/GEO-NERC Lead Agency Agreement. This Agreement allows a single joint US/UK proposal to be submitted and peer-reviewed by the Agency whose investigator has the largest proportion of the budget. Each Agency funds the proportion of the budget and the investigators associated with its own country. UK participation in this project includes deploying scientists as part of the field team, supporting field and sampling logistics at remote Antarctic sites, and genome sequencing, annotation, and analyses.  

This project focuses on the key physiological adaptations and molecular processes that allow a select few insect species to survive in Antarctica. The focal species are all wingless with limited dispersal capacity, suggesting there is also significant potential to locally adapt to variable environmental conditions across the range of these species. The central hypothesis is that similar molecular mechanisms drive both population-level adaptation to local environmental conditions and macroevolutionary changes across species living in different environments. The specific aims of the project are to 1) Characterize conserved and species-specific adaptations to extreme environments through comparative physiology and transcriptomics, 2) Compare the genome sequences of these species to identify genetic signatures of extreme adaption, and 3) Investigate patterns of diversification and local adaptation across each species? range using population genomics. The project establishes an international collaboration of researchers from the US, UK, Chile, and France with shared interests and complementary expertise in the biology, genomics, and conservation of Antarctic arthropods. The Broader Impacts of the project include training students and partnering with the Living Arts and Science Center to design and implement educational content for K-12 students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Insects are the most diverse and abundant animals on the planet, but Antarctica is the exception to that rule. A single insect species, the midge Belgica antarctica, is endemic to the continent (see image), and it has a suite of adaptations to cope with Antarctica’s harsh terrestrial environments. A second insect, the midge Eretmoptera murphyi, has invaded a single island in Antarctica and is at risk of outcompeting the native species. In our project, we used comparative physiology, genomics, and population genetics to investigate adaptations in Antarctic insects.

We exposed larvae of both midge species to a range of harsh environments in the laboratory and determined their ability to survive. Our results indicate that the native species (B. antarctica) is more tolerant of freezing, in that it can survive lower temperatures and remain frozen for a longer period without perishing. The native species is also slightly more heat tolerant, while both species have similar abilities to survive immersion in fresh water and sea water.

In B. antarctica, we determined potential consequences of simulated winter warming. Winter is warming faster than any other season in the Antarctic Peninsula, and using programmable incubators in the laboratory, we exposed larvae to three different winters (normal, cold, and warm) for six months. The warm winter led to poor survival, which was primarily due to depleted energy reserves. Thus, these cold-adapted species appear to be vulnerable to winter warming.

While cold is the most conspicuous feature of Antarctic environments, larvae experience a range of harsh environmental conditions, including dramatic shifts in temperature, dehydrating conditions, and submersion in fresh water or sea water. Cross-tolerance is an adaptation for coping with multiple stressors in which where exposure to one type of environmental stress can enhance tolerance to other stressors. We found that larvae can use cross-tolerance to enhance freeze tolerance; exposure to mild cold, heat, dehydration, and immersion in either fresh or salt water all enhanced freezing tolerance. However, for other severe stressors we tested (heat, dehydration, and high salinity environments), pre-exposure to mild stressors had little impact on larvae’s ability to survive, and in some cases reduced survival. Thus, larvae are finely tuned to enhance freezing tolerance via cross-tolerance, while tolerance to other stressors is not positively impacted by cross-tolerance. To identify mechanisms that drive cross-tolerance, we are using transcriptomics, proteomics, and metabolomics. From our transcriptomics analyses, while some gene expression modules are shared by distinct stressors (most notably a class of genes called heat shock proteins), most gene expression changes are specific to a single stressor, suggesting that responses to distinct stressors may have evolved independently.

In the second aim, we improved the genome assembly of B. antarctica while generating the first genomic resources for E. murphyi to facilitate comparative genomic analyses. To improve the genome assembly for B. antarctica, we used a new technology that permits longer sequence reads, and we saw a ~10-fold improvement in the quality of our assembly. While similar analyses for E. murphyi were delayed due to the pandemic, we have generated short read DNA and RNA sequences to begin building a genome for this species, which will facilitate in-depth comparative analyses to identify conserved and species-specific genomic adaptations to extreme environments.

In the final aim of the grant, we used population genetics and organismal physiology to compare distinct populations of Antarctic midges across their geographic range. Adults of the Antarctic midge are wingless, which limits gene flow and creates conditions suitable for local adaptation. We collected samples of Antarctic midges from ~25 different islands along the Antarctic Peninsula, which represents the single largest collection of Antarctic insects in history. Using whole genome resequencing, we characterized patterns of demography and found that while midges from different parts of Antarctica form distinct population clusters, there is more gene flow between populations that we anticipated. We also compared stress tolerance in larvae from distinct populations, and we observed significant variation in both survival to freezing and molecular responses to freezing, suggesting that larvae from different parts of Antarctica could be independently evolving to local conditions.

The Broader Impacts of this project were primarily focused on training the next generation of scientists and K-12 outreach. The project supported three graduate students, a postdoctoral researcher, and several undergraduate students. We also partnered with the Living Arts and Science Center, a local nonprofit in Lexington, KY, to develop educational content for their afterschool program. An educator from Living Arts and Science Center also joined our first field team in 2020, generating a live blog and interacting with students back in the US. We also collaborated with three authors to develop content on Antarctic midges for children’s books, and two of those have been published, including How Do Meerkats Order Pizza, a high selling book that discusses strange animals and the scientists who work on them.
